title: The valuable Iranian prisoner Australia traded for two jailed travel bloggers
text:
A scientist has been revealed as the prisoner traded for British travel blogger and her Australian boyfriend jailed in Iran.

Iranian scientist Reza Dehbashi Kivi, 38, was arrested in Brisbane in September 2018 after allegedly exporting American radar equipment back to Iran, which goes against US sanctions on the country.

He was help in custody for 13 months but was released to return to Iran on the same day as Perth based travel bloggers Mark Firkin and Jolie King were released.

Iranian scientist Reza Dehbashi Kivi (pictured) has been revealed as the valuable prisoner traded for two jailed Australian travel bloggers in Iran

Mr Dehbashi Kivi was also charged with 'aiding and abetting in the exportation of defence articles from the United States to Iran' and faced 20 years in jail if extradited.

Mr Firkin and Ms King had been detained in Tehran's notorious Evin Prison after being arrested three months ago after flying a drone near restricted airspace.

Mr Dehbashi Kivi was studying his PhD at the University of Queensland when he was arrested in his Redbank Plains home and denied bail.

His study included developing a machine which could detect skin cancers.

However his resume counts his areas of expertise as transformation optics and metamaterials, meaning he was studying the viability of 'invisibility cloaks'.

He had been fighting extradition to the United States ever since his arrest.

On Sunday Iranian television aired footage of Mr Dehbashi Kivi arriving back in the country (pictured)

The US wanted to extradite Mr Dehbashi Kivi on six charges including conspiring to export special amplifiers, classified by the US military, ABC News reported.

On Sunday Iranian television aired footage of Mr Dehbashi Kivi arriving back in the country.

Despite the release of Mr Firkin and Ms King at the same time Attorney-General Christian Porter said the cases weren't linked by an official statement.

'The Australian Government does not comment on the details behind its consideration of particular cases,' he said.

'And while it is likely that because of Mr Dehbashi Kivi's nationality some will speculate regarding this matter, consistent with prior practice I do not intend to comment further on the particular details of this case, particularly when any such response from me may diminish our Government's capacity to deal with future matters of this type in Australia's best interests.'
description: A scientist has been revealed as the valuable prisoner traded for British travel blogger and her Australian boyfriend jailed in Iran.
authors: Adam Mccleery For Daily Mail Australia
